review.title: Wind ramp event prediction with parallelized Gradient Boosted Regression Trees
review.abstract: Accurate prediction of wind ramp events is critical for ensuring the reliability and stability of the power systems with high penetration of wind energy. This paper proposes a classification based approach for estimating the future class of wind ramp event based on certain thresholds. A parallelized gradient boosted regression tree based technique has been proposed to accurately classify the normal as well as rare extreme wind power ramp events. The model has been validated using wind power data obtained from the National Renewable Energy Laboratory database. Performance comparison with several benchmark techniques indicates the superiority of the proposed technique in terms of superior classification accuracy.

sections.heading: VI. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Gradient-enhanced regression trees are a powerful class of models for predicting learning patterns from a variety of datasets. They have been shown to be robust to overfit, easy to train, and compact to use at test date. This work shows that predicting events on wind ramps is possible from large historical datasets by paralleling the learning process of gradient-enhanced trees on multi-core machines with a large number of cores. The performance of the GBRT model is compared with the performance of modern pattern recognition and machine learning, such as support vector machines, Artificial Neural Networks, Long Short Term Memory Neural Networks, and Random Forests. Comparison is performed on two datasets from wind farms in Alberta, and the GBRT model shows that both datasets perform well across three metrics. In addition to the regularly used metrics of accuracy and F1 score, we have introduced an additional metric to evaluate the precedent models for these events.
